image.altText: A for sale sign outside a suburban home

title.children: Half a million households brace for higher interest rates by the end of the year as the mortgage cliff looms

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe raised her first to the air in front of a Central Australian road sign

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese wearing a Yes hooded sweatshirt during a press conference.

props.synopsis: Known for its prolific advertising and catchy jingle, Chickenfeed forced its way into the Tasmanian psyche in the 1990s. Now a decade on from its downfall, nostalgia for the variety store is as strong as ever.

image.altText: A black and white collage of two women - one with short hair and one with long hair - looking at the camera

props.synopsis: Townsville is emerging as Australia's new Army capital with hundreds of soldiers to be relocated over coming years, while Adelaide becomes the home of advanced land-based, long-range strike technology.

image.altText: Flames above a large battery box behind a fence at night time

image.altText: A man lies in hospital with a tube coming from his nose

image.altText: A soldier waves a Ukrainian flag with his right hand as he holds a rifle in his left hand while standing atop a concrete block.

props.synopsis: Newcastle fullbacks Kalyn Ponga and Tamika Upton win the top NRL and NRLW awards at the Dally M awards night.

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell celebrates as Virat Kohli walks away.

image.altText: The left unenhanced visual of a blonde woman next to the right yassified version of her.

props.synopsis: Pictures of celebrities taken before-and-after they've allegedly undergone cosmetic procedures have probably popped up on your Explore page. But is it healthy for us to consume? And do their influence and high-profile lives give us the right to dissect celebrities' appearance?

title.children: Celebrity before-and-after surgery content is huge online. Who benefits from it?

image.altText: Child in the crowd wears green and gold Matildas jersey that reads 'Kerr'

props.synopsis: Retail spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup, the latest figures show.

title.children: Retail spending continues to enjoy Matildas boost as ASX recovers from early losses

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The rate of growth in monthly retail turnover continued to slow in August: When looking at the different segments of retail spending, food retailing and household goods retailing shrank. Spending was supported by clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing, other retailing, and cafes, restaurants and takeaway food. Altogether, it helped the total value of retail turnover increase by just 0.2 per cent. If you squint you can see it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: August retail spending: the story in graphs

children.content: The rate of growth in monthly retail turnover continued to slow in August:
When looking at the different segments of retail spending, food retailing and household goods retailing shrank.
Spending was supported by clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing, other retailing, and cafes, restaurants and takeaway food.
Altogether, it helped the total value of retail turnover increase by just 0.2 per cent.
If you squint you can see it.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics has released retail trade figures for August. They show retail turnover rose by 0.2 per cent in August, down from 0.5 per cent in July. Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, says the modest increase in retail spending shows consumers "continued to restrain their retail spending" last month. In fact, in trend terms, retail turnover rose 0.1 per cent, and was up only 1.3 per cent compared to August 2022 — the smallest trend growth over 12 months in the history of the series. "Considering how high inflation and strong population growth has added to retail turnover in the past year, the historically low trend growth highlights just how much consumers have pulled back in response to cost-of-living pressures," he said. Clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing (+1.3 per cent) recorded the largest rise, followed by cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services (+0.7 per cent), other retailing (+0.7 per cent), and department stores (+0.4 per cent). Spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup with strong demand for fan gear and increased spending across cafes, restaurants and takeaway food outlets as large crowds attended matches and live sites across the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail turnover up a paltry 0.2 per cent, but helped by Women's World Cup

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics has released retail trade figures for August.
They show retail turnover rose by 0.2 per cent in August, down from 0.5 per cent in July.
Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, says the modest increase in retail spending shows consumers
"continued to restrain their retail spending"
last month.
In fact, in trend terms, retail turnover rose 0.1 per cent, and was up only 1.3 per cent compared to August 2022 —
the smallest trend growth over 12 months in the history of the series.

"Considering how high inflation and strong population growth has added to retail turnover in the past year, the historically low trend growth highlights just how much consumers have pulled back in response to cost-of-living pressures," he said.

Clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing (+1.3 per cent) recorded the largest rise, followed by cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services (+0.7 per cent), other retailing (+0.7 per cent), and department stores (+0.4 per cent).
Spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup
with strong demand for fan gear and increased spending across cafes, restaurants and takeaway food outlets as large crowds attended matches and live sites across the country.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas' share price is up today, by quite a lot. It's up 3 per cent right now, which puts it into the top 10 biggest movers so far. And have a look at this. It shows how the share price really started climbing after 3pm yesterday. That was when new Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson, chairman Richard Goyder, and general counsel and group executive Andrew Finch appeared before a parliamentary committee in Canberra to talk about Bilateral Air Service Agreements (i.e. Qatar Airways and that whole controversy). They obviously performed well in the eyes of analysts and traders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How did Qantas' new CEO do facing questions from MPs?

children.content: Qantas' share price is up today, by quite a lot.
It's
up 3 per cent
right now, which puts it into the top 10 biggest movers so far.
And have a look at this. It shows how the share price really started climbing after 3pm yesterday.
That was when new
Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson
, chairman
Richard Goyder
, and general counsel and group executive
Andrew Finch
appeared before a parliamentary committee in Canberra to talk about Bilateral Air Service Agreements (i.e. Qatar Airways and that whole controversy).
They obviously performed well in the eyes of analysts and traders.
